siteMetadata.title: Autokin Automation
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using the Apollo GraphQL Client with React

children.value: React-Apollo includes a component for providing a client instance to a React component tree, and a higher-order component for retrieving that client instance.
Makes the GraphQL client available to any of your components enhanced by the
component works the same as the
instance to all of your GraphQL components that either use the
If you do not add this component to the root of your React tree then your components enhanced with Apollo capabilities will not be able to function.
instance will be used by all of your components enhanced with GraphQL capabilties.
If you want to get direct access to your
in your components then be sure to look at the
To access the client directly, create an
component and provide a render prop function as its child. The render prop function will be called with your
instance as its only argument. You can think of the
The Query component accepts the following props. Only
A GraphQL query document parsed into an AST by `graphql-tag`. **Required**
A function returning the UI you want to render based on your query result. **Required**
An object containing all of the variables your query needs to execute
Specifies the interval in ms at which you want your component to poll for data. Defaults to 0 (no polling).
Whether updates to the network status or network error should re-render your component. Defaults to false.
How you want your component to interact with the Apollo cache. Defaults to "cache-first".
How you want your component to handle network and GraphQL errors. Defaults to "none", which means we treat GraphQL errors as runtime errors.
Pass in false to skip your query during server-side rendering.
The name of your component to be displayed in React DevTools. Defaults to 'Query'.
If skip is true, the query will be skipped entirely.
A callback executed once your query successfully completes.
A callback executed in the event of an error.
Shared context between your Query component and your network interface (Apollo Link). Useful for setting headers from props or sending information to the `request` function of Apollo Boost.

If `true`, perform a query `refetch` if the query result is marked as being partial, and the returned data is reset to an empty Object by the Apollo Client `QueryManager` (due to a cache miss). The default value is `false` for backwards-compatibility's sake, but should be changed to true for most use-cases.
An `ApolloClient` instance. By default `Query` uses the client passed down via context, but a different client can be passed in.
Opt into receiving partial results from the cache for queries that are not fully satisfied by the cache. `false` by default.
The render prop function that you pass to the
) that has the following properties. This object contains your query result, plus some helpful functions for refetching, dynamic polling, and pagination.
An object containing the result of your GraphQL query. Defaults to `undefined`.
A boolean that indicates whether the request is in flight
A runtime error with `graphQLErrors` and `networkError` properties
An object containing the variables the query was called with

A number from 1-8 corresponding to the detailed state of your network request. Includes information about refetching and polling status. Used in conjunction with the `notifyOnNetworkStatusChange` prop.
A function that allows you to refetch the query and optionally pass in new variables
`fetchMore`: ({ query?: DocumentNode, variables?: TVariables, updateQuery: Function}) => Promise<ApolloQueryResult>
A function that enables [pagination](../features/pagination/) for your query
This function sets up an interval in ms and fetches the query each time the specified interval passes.
This function stops the query from polling.
`subscribeToMore`: (options: { document: DocumentNode, variables?: TVariables, updateQuery?: Function, onError?: Function}) => () => void
A function that sets up a [subscription](../advanced/subscriptions/). `subscribeToMore` returns a function that you can use to unsubscribe.
A function that allows you to update the query's result in the cache outside the context of a fetch, mutation, or subscription
Your `ApolloClient` instance. Useful for manually firing queries or writing data to the cache.
The Mutation component accepts the following props. Only
A GraphQL mutation document parsed into an AST by `graphql-tag`. **Required**
A function that allows you to trigger a mutation from your UI. **Required**
An object containing all of the variables your mutation needs to execute
A function used to update the cache after a mutation occurs
If true, the `data` property on the render prop function will not update with the mutation result.
Provide a [mutation response](../features/optimistic-ui/) before the result comes back from the server
`refetchQueries`: (mutationResult: FetchResult) => Array<{ query: DocumentNode, variables?: TVariables}>
A function that allows you to specify which queries you want to refetch after a mutation has occurred
A callback executed once your mutation successfully completes
A callback executed in the event of an error
Shared context between your Mutation component and your network interface (Apollo Link). Useful for setting headers from props or sending information to the `request` function of Apollo Boost.
An `ApolloClient` instance. By default `Mutation` uses the client passed down via context, but a different client can be passed in.
The render prop function that you pass to the
function and an object with the mutation result. The
function is how you trigger the mutation from your UI. The object contains your mutation result, plus loading and error state.

A function to trigger a mutation from your UI. You can optionally pass `variables`, `optimisticResponse`, `refetchQueries`, and `update` in as options, which will override any props passed to the `Mutation` component. The function returns a promise that fulfills with your mutation result.
The data returned from your mutation. It can be undefined if `ignoreResults` is true.
A boolean indicating whether your mutation is in flight
Any errors returned from the mutation
A boolean indicating if the mutate function has been called
Your `ApolloClient` instance. Useful for invoking cache methods outside the context of the update function, such as `client.writeData` and `client.readQuery`.
The Subscription component accepts the following props. Only
A GraphQL subscription document parsed into an AST by `graphql-tag`. **Required**
A function returning the UI you want to render based on your subscription result. **Required**
An object containing all of the variables your subscription needs to execute
Determines if your subscription should be unsubscribed and subscribed again

Allows the registration of a callback function, that will be triggered each time the `Subscription` component receives data. The callback `options` object param consists of the current Apollo Client instance in `client`, and the received subscription data in `subscriptionData`.
How you want your component to interact with the Apollo cache. Defaults to "cache-first".
An `ApolloClient` instance. By default `Subscription` uses the client passed down via context, but a different client can be passed in.
The render prop function that you pass to the
is called with an object that has the following properties
An object containing the result of your GraphQL subscription. Defaults to an empty object.
A boolean that indicates whether any initial data has been returned
A runtime error with `graphQLErrors` and `networkError` properties

that doesn't send out network requests to your API but rather allows you to specify the exact response payload for a given request.

function is the most important thing exported by

function, after your GraphQL document. The config is optional and allows you to add some custom behavior to your higher order component.
Lets go through all of the properties that may live on your

The function you define behaves almost exactly like
providing the same benefits without the need for another library.
is most useful when you want to abstract away complex functions calls into a simple prop that you can pass down to your component.

is that it also allows you to decouple your pure UI components from your GraphQL and Apollo concerns. You can write your pure UI components in one file and then keep the logic required for them to interact with the store in a completely different place in your project. You can accomplish this by your pure UI components only asking for the props needed to render and
can contain the logic to provide exactly the props your pure component needs from the data provided by your GraphQL API.
To access props that are not added by the
is true then all of the React Apollo code will be skipped
. It will be as if the
function were a simple identity function. Your component will behave as if the
function were not there at all.
Instead of passing a boolean to
, you may also pass a function to
. The function will take your components props and should return a boolean. If the boolean returns true then the skip behavior will go into effect.
is especially useful if you want to use a different query based on some prop. You can see this in an example below.
// The data may be from `MyQuery1` or `MyQuery2` depending on the value
This property allows you to configure the name of the prop that gets passed down to your component. By default if the GraphQL document you pass into
is a query then your prop will be named
. If you pass a mutation then your prop will be named
. While appropriate these default names collide when you are trying to use multiple queries or mutations with the same component. To avoid collisions you may use
to provide the prop from each query or mutation HOC a new name.
// Instead of the default prop name, `mutate`,

to true you will be able to get the instance of your wrapped component from your higher-order GraphQL component using a
method available on the instance of your higher-order GraphQL component.
You may want to set this to true when you want to call functions or get access to properties that are defined on your wrapped components class instance.
Below you can see an example of this behavior.
// We can call methods on the component class instance.
By default the display name for React Apollo components is

. This is a pattern used by most React libraries that make use of higher order components. However, it may get a little confusing when you are using more than one higher order component and you look at the
To configure the name of your higher order component wrapper, you may use the
property. So for example, if you set

The higher-order component created when using
prop into your component. Like so:

prop contains the data fetched from your query in addition to some other useful information and functions to control the lifecycle of your GraphQL-connected component. So for example, if we had a query that looked like:
// <- The data returned by your query for `viewer`.
// <- The data returned by your query for `todos`.
prop has some other useful properties which can be accessed directly from
in your components before rendering. Properties like
which contain your apps data may be undefined while your component is performing its initial fetch. Checking
helps you avoid any issues with undefined data. Such checks may look like:

A boolean representing whether or not a query request is currently in flight for this component. This means that a query request has been sent using your network interface, and we have not yet gotten a response back. Use this property to render a loading component.
is true it does not mean that you wont have data. For instance, if you already have
, but you want to get the latest todos from your API
might be true, but you will still have the todos from your previous request.
There are multiple different network states that your query may be in. If you want to see what the network state of your component is in more detail then refer to
If an error occurred then this property will be an instance of
. If you do not handle this error you will get a warning in your console that says something like:

is useful if you want to display a different loading indicator (or no indicator at all) depending on your network status as it provides a more detailed view into the state of a network request on your component than
is an enum with different number values between 1 and 8. These number values each represent a different network state.
: The query has never been run before and the request is now pending. A query will still have this network status even if a result was returned from the cache, but a query was dispatched anyway.
: If a querys variables change and a network request was fired then the network status will be
until the result of that query comes back. React users will see this when
was called on this query and that the network request created is currently in flight.
was called on a query and the refetch request is currently in flight.
: Indicates that a polling query is currently in flight. So for example if you are polling a query every 10 seconds then the network status will switch to
every 10 seconds whenever a poll request has been sent but not resolved.
: No request is in flight for this query, and no errors happened. Everything is OK.
: No request is in flight for this query, but one or more errors were detected.
If the network status is less then 7 then it is equivalent to
being true. In fact you could replace all of your
and you would not see a difference. It is recommended that you use

The variables that Apollo used to fetch data from your GraphQL endpoint. This property is helpful if you want to render some information based on the variables that were used to make a request against your server.

// Only unsubscribe/update state if subscription variable has changed

This function will set up an interval and send a fetch request every time that interval ellapses. The function takes only one integer argument which allows you to configure how often you want your query to be executed in milliseconds. In other words, the
argument represents the milliseconds between polls.

Polling is a good way to keep the data in your UI fresh. By refetching your data every 5,000 milliseconds (or 5 seconds, for example) you may effectively emulate realtime data without needing to build up a realtime backend.
when your query is already polling then the current polling process will be cancelled and a new process will be started with the interval you specified.
to start polling immediately after your component mounts. It is recommend that you use
if you dont need to arbitrarily start and stop polling.
to 0 then that means no polling instead of executing a request every JavaScript event loop tick.
// In this specific case you may want to use `options.pollInterval` instead.
By calling this function you will stop any current polling process. Your query will not start polling again until you call

This function allows you to update the data for your query outside of the context of any mutation, subscription, or fetch. This function only takes a single argument which will be another function. The argument function has the following signature:

The first argument will be the data for your query that currently exists in the store, and you are expected to return a new data object with the same shape. That new data object will be written to the store and any components tracking that data will be updated reactively.
The second argument is an object with a single property,
property allows you to see what variables were used when reading the
update anything on the server. It will only update data in your client cache and if you reload your JavaScript environment then your update will disappear.
An object or function that returns an object of options that are used to configure how the query is fetched and updated.
is a function then it will take the components props as its first argument.
The options available for use  in this object depend on the operation type you pass in as the first argument to
. The references below will document which options are available when your operation is a query. To see what other options are available for different operations, see the generic documentation for
The variables that will be used when executing the query operation. These variables should correspond with the variables that your query definition accepts. If you define
as a function then you may compute your variables from your props.

The fetch policy is an option which allows you to specify how you want your component to interact with the Apollo data cache. By default your component will try to read from the cache first, and if the full data for your query is in the cache then Apollo simply returns the data from the cache. If the full data for your query is
in the cache then Apollo will execute your request using your network interface. By changing this option you can change this behavior.

: This is the default value where we always try reading data from your cache first. If all the data needed to fulfill your query is in the cache then that data will be returned. Apollo will only fetch from the network if a cached result is not available. This fetch policy aims to minimize the number of network requests sent when rendering your component.

: This fetch policy will have Apollo first trying to read data from your cache. If all the data needed to fulfill your query is in the cache then that data will be returned. However, regardless of whether or not the full data is in your cache this
execute query with the network interface unlike

which will only execute your query if the query data is not in your cache. This fetch policy optimizes for users getting a quick response while also trying to keep cached data consistent with your server data at the cost of extra network requests.

return you initial data from the cache. Instead it will always make a request using your network interface to the server. This fetch policy optimizes for data consistency with the server, but at the cost of an instant response to the user when one is available.

execute a query using your network interface. Instead it will always try reading from the cache. If the data for your query does not exist in the cache then an error will be thrown. This fetch policy allows you to only interact with data in your local client cache without making any network requests which keeps your component fast, but means your local data might not be consistent with what is on the server. If you are interested in only interacting with data in your Apollo Client cache also be sure to look at the
methods available to you on your
return your initial data from the cache. Instead it will always make a request using your network interface to the server. Unlike the
policy, it also will not write any data to the cache after the query completes.

The error policy is an option which allows you to specify how you want your component to handle errors that can happen when fetching data from GraphQL. There are two types of errors that can happen during your request; a runtime error on the client or server which results in no data, or some GraphQL errors which may be delivered alongside actual data. In order to control how your UI interacts with these errors, you can use the error policy to tell Apollo when you want to know about GraphQL Errors or not!
: This is the default value where we treat GraphQL errors as runtime errors. Apollo will discard any data that came back with the request and render your component with an
, this causes Apollo to ignore any data from your server, but it also won't update your UI aside from setting the loading state back to false.

: Selecting all means you want to be notified any time there are any GraphQL errors. It will render your component with any data from the request and any errors with their information. It is particularly helpful for server side rendering so your UI always shows something

The interval in milliseconds at which you want to start polling. Whenever that number of milliseconds elapses your query will be executed using the network interface and another execution will be scheduled using the configured number of milliseconds.
This option will start polling your query immediately when the component mounts. If you want to start and stop polling dynamically then you may use
to 0 then that means no polling instead of executing a request every JavaScript event loop tick.
Whether or not updates to the network status or network error should trigger re-rendering of your component.
With the flexiblity and power of
being part of Apollo Client, you may want to send information from your operation straight to a link in your network chain! This can be used to do things like set
on HTTP requests from props, control which endpoint you send a query to, and so much more depending on what links your app is using. Everything under the
object gets passed directly to your network chain. For more information about using context, check out the

The variables which will be used to execute the mutation operation. These variables should correspond to the variables that your mutation definition accepts. If you define

Often when you mutate data it is fairly easy to predict what the response of the mutation will be before asking your server. The optimistic response option allows you to make your mutations feel faster by simulating the result of your mutation in your UI before the mutation actually finishes.
To learn more about the benefits of optimistic data and how to use it be sure to read the recipe on
This optimistic response will be used with
to apply an update to your cache which will be rolled back before applying the update from the actual response.
// The optimistic response has all of the fields that are included in
// A temporary id. The server decides the real id.

This option allows you to update your store based on your mutations result. By default Apollo Client will update all of the overlapping nodes in your store. Anything that shares the same id as returned by the

you defined will be updated with the new fields from your mutation results. However, sometimes this alone is not sufficient. Sometimes you may want to update your cache in a way that is dependent on the data currently in your cache. For these updates you may use an
takes two arguments. The first is an instance of a

object which has some methods which will allow you to interact with the data in your store. The second is the response from your mutation - either the optimistic response, or the actual response returned by your server (see the mutation result described in the
In order to change the data in your store call methods on your
. This will update your cache and reactively re-render any of your GraphQL components which are querying affected data.

Sometimes when you make a mutation you also want to update the data in your queries so that your users may see an up-to-date user interface. There are more fine-grained ways to update the data in your cache which include
. However, you can update the data in your cache more reliably at the cost of efficiency by using

will execute one or more queries using your network interface and will then normalize the results of those queries into your cache. Allowing you to potentially refetch queries you had fetched before, or fetch brand new queries.
is either an array of strings or objects, or a function which takes the result of the mutation and returns an array of strings or objects.

is an array of strings then Apollo Client will look for any queries with the same names as the provided strings and will refetch those queries with their current variables. So for example if you have a GraphQL query component with a query named
), and you pass an array of strings containing
query will be re-executed and when it resolves the latest data will be reflected in your UI.
is an array of objects then the objects must have two properties:
: Query is a required property that accepts a GraphQL query created with
template string tag. It should contain a single GraphQL query operation that will be executed once the mutation has completed.
: Is an optional object of variables that is required when
If an array of objects with this shape is specified then Apollo Client will refetch these queries with their variables.

Please note that refetched queries are handled asynchronously, and by default are not necessarily completed before the mutation has completed. If you want to make sure refetched queries are completed before the mutation is considered done (or resolved), set
are handled asynchronously, which means by default they are not necessarily completed before the mutation has completed. Setting
will make sure refetched queries are completed before the mutation is considered done (or resolved).
will be removed in the next version of Apollo Client
